bibl.idno: The Papers of Henry Rose Carter [manuscript] ; HEALTHSCI MS-10.

bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, September 5, 1928

div1.p: Carter and Brown continue to work intensively. Carter asks Russell to track down additional references that may be found in reports of the International Health Division of the Rockefeller Foundation.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, September 5, 1928
div1.opener:
Book, Misel
Russell
(Report)
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N.W.
Washington, D. C.
September 5, 1928.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
I wentoover to Baltimore last Friday with the bibliographic
file for the work done at the Library of the Surgeon General of the Army
and stayed, and worked, at the Frosts until Labor Day. Dr. Frost was
surprised and pleased at the amount Miss Brown and myself had accomplishe
and hopes that he can start the final editing of the MSS by the end of the
second or third week of September. He thinks, however, that I had best
stay in Washington for about five days of each week and go over to Balti-
more for the other two: this because the references still to be verified
have a better chance of being done here than in Baltimore, and Miss Brown
and I together are more likely to trace them than she would be by herself.
Of course, all routine methods of proceedure have already been tried:
Index Medicus: Index of the Surgeon General and the Index of the Library c
Congress and those of foreign and other domestic libraries kept in the Library of Congress and
the Library of the S. G. We are still finding things, however, by bib-
liographies of other books: writing to various authors quoted in Father's
book: personal interviews etc. etc. In this connection, I should be very
grateful if, in addition to the short list of incomplete references I
sent you on August 16th. (re matters of which I thought your Division
would be cognizant) you would ask someone to complete the enclosed ref-
erences, which I think must be from material in your files (Reports etc.)
as both Miss Brown and I have made exhaustive search for them elsewhere.
Incidentally I have heard nothing from the first list I sent you, but hope
I shall later, as those references also had been searched for here at length.

I hope, when you come to Washington, that you will be able
to come to my apartment, as I should like to show you the locker truck
trunk-
-2-
ful of Father's bibliographic notes, both because I know they would in-
terest you in themselves and also explain what must have otherwise have
seemed an unproductive period after my return from the Hopkins: a period
which was, on the contrary, the reason Miss Brown and I have been able
to do so much in so short a time. after starting work at the
libraries.

I shall try to write you more later in the week, but Miss
Brown has arrived for a night session, she having used up mostso much of her
annual leave working for me at the Library of the Surgeon General that
I am trying to supplement it with work at times that will not count against
it. I judge that we shall work together intensively all through September
and can't begin to tell you what a help she has been, and is.

With best remembrances, and looking forward to seeing you
when you come to Washington,
div1.closer:
Most truly yours, Laura A. Carter Enclosures.
Dr. Frederick F. Russell, Director,
International Health Division,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
